title: Poor in India who can't afford to fly given tickets to board plane bought by kind-hearted retired engineer for £60,000
text:
View
comments
A retired engineer is offering flights to India's poor for free - but the airplane never leaves the ground.
Bahadur Chand Gupta, 58, from Haryana in northern India, purchased a decommissioned Airbus 300 in 2003 for 6,000,000 rupees (£60,000).
Parked on the outskirts of New Delhi, on the perimeter of the capital's International airport, the plane is mostly visited by children and the region's underprivileged citizens who have never had the chance to board an aircraft.
Retired Indian Airlines flight engineer Bahadur Chand Gupta poses inside the out-of-service Airbus A300
Children with their 'boarding passes' wait in a queue to enter the aircraft and prepare for their first 'flight'
Gupta guides a group of local villagers inside the plane, which he purchased for 6,000,000 rupees (£60,000)
Two boys excitedly show their 'boarding passes' after they are seated at the front of the aircraft
Visitors, who are given tickets before boarding the out-of-service Airbus, are served sweets by 'air attendants' Ridhi Sehgal, Pratibha Dalal and Sapna Singh.

Gupta, an engineer who formerly worked with Indian Airlines, charges visitors according to their social status - if they are poor they can board for free and if they're middle class they're asked to pay $1 (65p).
He also demonstrates how to control an aircraft and how to evacuate an airplane in an emergency - including a go on the functioning slide.
The 'Captain' poses with flight attendants Ridhi Sehgal (left), Pratibha Dalal (second right) and Sapna Singh (right)
A boy clutches his ticket and smiles as he learns to slide from an emergency exit of the Airbus 300
Four boys enjoy the flight experience - in which they are given free lunches and sweets from 'crew'
Villagers are seated on the plane, which is parked on the outskirts of New Delhi's International airport
The flight-mad philanthropist, who also provides free lunch to poor people on board, says he has succeeded in his mission to give the region's poor the chance to experience air travel.
Gupta said: 'I belong to a very small village in Haryana.
'When I was working, people from my village used to ask me about the aircraft.
'Many of my friends in my villages used to ask if I could take them inside an airport so that they can see the aircraft from close quarters as they could not afford to travel in an Airbus.'
Flight attendant Pratibha Dalal smiles with a passenger as he pretends to steer the plane from the cockpit
Complimentary snacks: Sweets are handed out by air attendants from a trolley throughout the experience
He added: 'I took my friend inside the airport somehow but the authorities caught me.
'Then I decided to sell my land so that I can buy an Airbus.'
'If the person is poor, we don't charge him and if the person comes from a middle class family, we charge him 1$.
'Lot of people used to come to see the plane but now people are not coming in that number as most of them have already seen it.
'I train people for the emergencies. We teach them how save lives in case of fire and how to jump from the aircraft.'
Bahadur Chand Gupta explains how to fly a plane to a group of children from a nearby village in New Dehli
This is your captain speaking: Gupta poses as the pilot in the cockpit of the aircraft, which he bought in 2003
